From the Contributors to the Calories- Exploration of Recipes

Introduction

I am a hungry person, both for knowledge and food (ğŸ˜†). Consequently, I decided that the most interesting data to analyze would be recipes for delicious dishes. The recipes I analyzed are pulled directly from food.com. Each row in my dataframe contains a recipe, and each column contains useful information about the recipes. Displayed below is information about my dataframe, including the shape and column names.

Shape of the Recipes Dataframe:

So what was I working with once I cleaned the data and was left with my dataframe ready for analysis?

print(recipes.shape)

(234429, 24)

The above result from the code means that there are 234,429 rows and 24 columns in my recipes dataframe!

Exploratory data analysis (EDA) Question:

Which contributors consistently have the highest average recipe ratings?

This is an important question to think about, because if I am ever super hungry in the future (and also actually learn how to cook), I will know which contributorsâ€™ recipes to look at. Perhaps I can also learn to cook by following these top contributors. After performing this EDA, we will know which contributors are the most esteemed on food.com.

Which columns were most important to my EDA?

print(recipes.columns.to_list())

[â€˜nameâ€™, â€˜idâ€™, â€˜minutesâ€™, â€˜contributor_idâ€™, â€˜submittedâ€™, â€˜tagsâ€™, â€˜n_stepsâ€™, â€˜stepsâ€™, â€˜descriptionâ€™, â€˜ingredientsâ€™, â€˜n_ingredientsâ€™, â€˜user_idâ€™, â€˜recipe_idâ€™, â€˜dateâ€™, â€˜ratingâ€™, â€˜reviewâ€™, â€˜caloriesâ€™, â€˜total_fatâ€™, â€˜sugarâ€™, â€˜sodiumâ€™, â€˜proteinâ€™, â€˜saturated_fatâ€™, â€˜carbohydratesâ€™, â€˜average_ratingâ€™]

Above is a list of all the column names in the cleaned recipes dataframe that I used for analysis.

The columns that are most related to my EDA were â€˜contributor_idâ€™, â€˜ratingâ€™, and â€˜average_ratingâ€™.

contributer_id: A unique way to identify the contributors (also known as primary key). This column is of type integer.
â€˜ratingâ€™: A single rating of the recipe given by a user. This column is of type integer.
â€˜average_ratingâ€™: The mean rating that a recipe was given. This column is of type float.

Data Cleaning and Exploratory Data Analysis

Cleaning the data involved reading the csv files, creating tables, merging the tables, and formatting the data so that it was easy to work with. The next three lines of code display how I attained the data from the csv files and merged them into one dataframe:

recipes_df = pd.read_csv('food_data/RAW_recipes.csv')
interactions_df = pd.read_csv('food_data/RAW_interactions.csv')
merged_df = pd.merge(recipes_df, interactions_df, how='left', left_on='id', right_on='recipe_id')

Once I had the merged dataframe, I had to make sure the data was easy to work with. Given that I was exploring a question relating to ratings of recipes, I checked out the distribution of ratings and visualized it (shown below).

As we can see, there are over 15,000 ratings of 0 stars. This is problematic because the rating scale is 1-5 stars, not inclusive of 0, so these ratings are probably from people who just left the star rating blank when writing their review. To be able to answer my question more accurately, I replaced all ratings of 0 with np.nan. The new distribution of ratings is shown below.

One more thing I did was I created an average_rating column. Originally, the data only had individual ratings for each review, so I thought it would be meaningful to group the dataframe by recipe_id, calculate the average rating for each recipe, and impute this data.

The last step I took in cleaning the data was by organizing the â€˜nutritionâ€™ column. The nutrition column contained information in the form of a string that looked like a list: â€œ[calories, total fat, sugar, sodium, protein, saturated fat, and carbohydrates]â€. I took this information and created separate columns called â€˜caloriesâ€™, â€˜total_fatâ€™, â€˜sugarâ€™, â€˜sodiumâ€™, â€˜proteinâ€™, â€˜saturated_fatâ€™, and â€˜carbohydratesâ€™. The head of my cleaned and tidy dataframe is shown below.

Univariate Analysis

So I had a clean dataframe, but whatâ€™s next? I was looking to answer the question â€œWhich contributors consistently have the highest average recipe ratings?â€ A good way to startanalyzing this was to create a column called â€˜num_contributionsâ€™ and display its distribution. I created the column â€˜num_contributionsâ€™ by grouping the dataframe by â€˜contributor_idâ€™ and counting how many times that contributor appeared. Given the sheer amount of contributors that contributed between 1-99 times, I decided to drop these datapoints when showing the distributions of â€˜num_contributionsâ€™. This made the data much less skewed and also more meaningful to look at, as my EDA question involved looking at contributors that consistently have the best ratings. Below is a boxplot showing the distribution of â€˜num_contributionsâ€™ for contributors who contributed more than 100 times.

As we can see, the median number of contributions for contributors that contributed over 100 times is 247. Interestingly, one contributor contributed 3,060 times (the maximum). That is one dedicated person!

Another interesting column to see the distribution of was the â€˜average_ratingâ€™ column. This column showed the average rating of recipes. However, to make the distribution meaningul, I had to first adjust the dataframe so that the recipe_id column only contained a recipe once. Since this column is an aggregate, there was no sense in displaying the average rating of a single recipe multiple times. Below shows how I did this in code:

unique_recipe_df = recipes.copy()
unique_recipe_df = unique_recipe_df.drop_duplicates('recipe_id')

Below is the distribution is shown in a histogram.

As we can see, food.com reviewers seem to be quite supportive on average. Most recipes got an average rating of 4 or above! Over 48,000 recipes got an average rating between 4.9 stars and 5 stars. Another interesting pattern is that the average ratings tend to be closer to integers (i.e. 1 star, 2 stars, 3 stars, etc) rather than decimals (i.e. 1.5 stars, 2.5 stars, 3.5 stars, etc).

contributor_id num_contributions avg_rating
2.19261e+06 106 5
306726 115 4.98949
2.39055e+06 360 4.97907
2.68903e+06 139 4.97448
2.21634e+06 140 4.97424
